sentences.original: kayâs ayîsiyiniwak mistahi kîh-kitimâkisiwak, oskac ôtêh êh-ayâcik, nama kêkway ohci ki-pakitinikôwisiwak.
sentences.text: kayâs ayîsiyiniwak mistahi kî-kitimâkisiwak oskac ôtê ê-ayâcik nama kêkway ohci kî-pakitinikôwisiwak
sentences.english: The people of old were in a piteous state, when first they lived here on earth. The Higher Powers had put them down here with nothing at all.

sentences.original: kîh-mosêskatêwak.
sentences.text: kî-mosêskatêwak
sentences.english: They went naked.

sentences.original: nama kêkway ayôwinisah ohc âyâwak; nama kêkway môhkomân.
sentences.text: nama kêkway ayiwinisa ohci ayâwak nama kêkway môhkomân
sentences.english: They had no clothes, no knives.

sentences.original: nayêstaw oskan kîh-omôhkomâniwak.
sentences.text: nayêstaw oskan kî-omôhkomâniwak
sentences.english: All they had for a knife was a bone.

sentences.original: nama kêkway ohc âyâwak iskotêw.
sentences.text: nama kêkway ohci ayâwak iskotêw
sentences.english: From the beginning they had no fire.

sentences.original: acosis pikoh kîh-ohcih-nipahêwak pisiskiwah, oskanah êh-kikamohtâcik wîpisisiwâhk.
sentences.text: acosis piko kî-ohci-nipahêwak pisiskiwa oskana ê-kikamohtâcik wîpisisiwâhk
sentences.english: With merely an arrow they killed animals, fastening bones to their arrows.

sentences.original: nama kêkway; kîh-kitimâkisiwak.
sentences.text: nama kêkway kî-kitimâkisiwak
sentences.english: They had nothing; they were in a piteous state.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê iskotêw kîh-osîhtamâsôwak, ômis êh-tôtahkik;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê iskotêw kî-osîhtamâsôwak ômisi ê-tôtahkik
sentences.english: Presently they made fire for themselves, doing it like this;
sentences.footnote: LB: Unfortunately I did not record the gesture.

sentences.original: êh-kisitêyik, piyisk êkotah kîh-ôtinamwak iskotêw.
sentences.text: ê-kisitêyik piyisk êkota kî-otinamwak iskotêw
sentences.english: when it was hot, they got fire from it.

sentences.original: piyisk asiniyah êh-pakamahwâcik, ê-wâsaskotêpayiyit, êkotê êkwah kiy-ôhtinamwak iskotêw ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.text: piyisk asiniya ê-pakamahwâcik ê-wâsaskotêpayiyit êkotê êkwa kî-ohtinamwak iskotêw ayîsiyiniwak
sentences.english: Also they pounded a stone, and when it sent out sparks, from this, too, the people got fire.

sentences.original: êkwah asiskiy kih-otaskihkowak.
sentences.text: êkwa asiskiy kî-otaskihkowak
sentences.english: Their pots and kettles were of earth.

sentences.original: mînah kîh-wâtihkêwak, pahkêkin êh-asiwatâcik, asiniyah êh-kisâpiskiswâcik; êyakôh ohci wiyâs êh-kîsisahkik.
sentences.text: mîna kî-wâtihkêwak pahkêkin ê-asiwatâcik asiniya ê-kisâpiskiswâcik êwako ohci wiyâs ê-kîsisahkik
sentences.english: Also, they would dig a hole and put in a hide, and heat some stones; in this way they cooked meat.

sentences.original: êkwah kîtahtawê amiskwayânah kîh-otayôwinisiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa kîtahtawê amiskwayâna kî-otayôwinisiwak
sentences.english: Then in time they began to have beaver-pelts for their clothes.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak kîh-pawâtam ê-wîh-kapâyit môniyâw-iyiniwa wâpiski-wiyâsah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê pêyak kî-pawâtam ê-wî-kapâyit môniyâw-iyiniwa wâpiski-wiyâsa
sentences.english: Then at one time a certain man dreamt that the Canadian, the White Man, would land here.

sentences.original: âcimôw tâyispîhk ta-kapâyit.
sentences.text: âcimôw tâyispîhk ta-kapâyit
sentences.english: He told when they would land.

sentences.original: tâpwê ânwêhtawâw; âtiht tâpwêhtâk.
sentences.text: tâpwê ânwêhtawâw âtiht tâpwêhtâk
sentences.english: Truly, he was not given credence; only some believed him.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotê mâmihk ispiciwak, cîkih kihcikamihk.
sentences.text: êkwa êkotê mâmihk ispiciwak cîki kihcikamîhk
sentences.english: Then they moved their camp out there to the east, close to the great sea.

sentences.original: êkwah wîpac kâ-wih-pê-kapâcik! itwêw;
sentences.text: itwêw
sentences.english: “Now the time is close at hand when they will land!” he said;

sentences.original: mâskôc ahpôh mitoni kiyipah, itêw ayîsiyiniwah.
sentences.text: itêw ayîsiyiniwa
sentences.english: “Surely very soon,” he told the people.

sentences.original: tahtoh kîkisêpâ ntaw-ây-itâpiw mâna nipîhk.
sentences.text: tahto kîkisêpâ nitawi-ay-itâpiw mâna nipîhk
sentences.english: Every morning he would go and look out upon the water.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-pêcâpahtahk cîmânah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-pêtisâpahtahk cîmâna
sentences.english: Then at one time he saw boats coming.

sentences.original: ôtah êh-pê-takohtêyit, sakicihcênitôwak; atamiskotâtôwak.
sentences.text: ôta ê-pê-takohtêyit sakicihcênitôwak atamiskotâtôwak
sentences.english: When the others arrived there, they shook each other by the hand and greeted each other.

sentences.original: cikêmâ êkosi nistam kâ-isih-wâpamât ayîsiyiniw wâpiski-wiyâsah.
sentences.text: cikêmâ êkosi nistam kâ-isi-wâpamât ayîsiyiniw wâpiski-wiyâsa
sentences.english: For, indeed, thus it was that the Indian first saw the Whiteskin.
sentences.footnote: LB on {ayîsiyiniw}:  Here unmistakably “Indian”; below {nêhiyaw}: “Cree” (kept in translation) is probably meant in the same way.  The proper term {wâpiski-wiyâs}: “white-flesh, white man” alternates with {môniyâw}: “Canadian” (kept in translation).

sentences.original: kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-miyik kit-ôh-pimâtisit : môhkoman, pâskisikan, kit-âpacihtât kahkiyaw kêkway pâskisikêwin.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw kêkway kî-miyik kita-ôh-pimâtisit môhkomân pâskisikan kita-âpacihtât kahkiyaw kêkway pâskisikêwin
sentences.english: They gave him everything to live by:  the knife and the gun and all kinds of ammunition for his use.

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah ohci kiskinôhamawâw kit-êsi-pamihtât pâskisikan.
sentences.text: êkosi êkota ohci kiskinôhamawâw kita-isi-pamihtât pâskisikan
sentences.english: So then he began to be taught how to take care of a gun.

sentences.original: êkotah ohci êkwah ati-miyw-âyâwak ayîsiyiniwak.
sentences.text: êkota ohci êkwa ati-miyw-âyâwak ayîsiyiniwak
sentences.english: From that time on the Indians were well off.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkotah ohci piyisk atimwah ayâwêwak, êh-otâpahâcik.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkota ohci piyisk atimwa ayâwêwak ê-otâpahâcik
sentences.english: At a certain time after this they began to have horses to pull their loads.
sentences.footnote: LB on {atimwah}: Properly “dogs”, but often used for {misatim}: “horse”; that this is here the case is shown by the next sentence.

sentences.original: ôtêh pikoh nimitâw ayîsiyiniwak okîh-ayâwâhtawâw kayahtê misatimwah;
sentences.text: ôtê piko nimitaw ayîsiyiniwak okî-ayâwâhtâwâw kayâhtê misatimwa
sentences.english: And, strangely enough, it was only the people in the south who had horses;

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc ohc âyâwêw ayîsiyiniw nâtakâm k-êtapit.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc ohci ayâwêw ayîsiyiniw nâtakâm kâ-itapit
sentences.english: the Indian who dwells in the north from that time to this has never had horses.

sentences.original: kîtahtawêh osâm êkâ kêkway êh-ayâcik mâmoscikêwin, kîtahtawê pêyak nâpêw otawâsimisah êh-nâ-nipahâpâkwêyit ,--
sentences.text: kîtahtawê osâm êkâ kêkway ê-ayâcik mawimoscikêwin kîtahtawê pêyak nâpêw otawâsimisa ê-nâ-nipahâpâkwêyit
sentences.english: Presently, because they had no way of worship, presently a certain man whose children had suffered to the point of death from thirst, --

sentences.original: kayâs êsah nama wîhkâc kêkway ômah askîhk ohcih ohpikin;
sentences.text: kayâs êsa nama wîhkâc kêkway ôma askîhk ohci ohpikin
sentences.english: for it seems that of old nothing ever grew from the earth;

sentences.original: ahpôh maskosiyah kîh-kîsitêwa ,--
sentences.text: ahpô maskosiya kî-kîsitêwa
sentences.english: only grass ripened, --

sentences.original: êkwah pêyak nâpêw osâm mistahih êh-miywâtisit, kîtahtawê kâ-wîhtamâkot okîsikowah, hâw, kik-êtohtahitin itêh kit-ôh-pimâtisiyin.
sentences.text: êkwa pêyak nâpêw osâm mistahi ê-miywâtisit kîtahtawê kâ-wîhtamâkot okîsikowa
sentences.english: then a certain man who was very good, was told by the dwellers in the sky, “Now I will take you whence you will have your source of life.”

sentences.original: êkwah tâpwê âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itohtayik mayaw êh-nipât;
sentences.text: êkwa tâpwê âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itohtahik mayaw ê-nipât
sentences.english: Then truly he was taken to the place of the noonday sky, even as he slept;

sentences.original: êkotê êh-pawâtahk, wîhtamâkôwisiw nipâkwêsimôwikamik.
sentences.text: êkotê ê-pawâtahk wîhtamâkôwisiw nipâkwêsimôwikamik
sentences.english: dreaming of that place, he was told by the Higher Powers of the Sun-Dance Lodge.

sentences.original: êwakoh tahtw-âskiy kita-tôtahkik ayîsiyiniwak kîh-miyâwak.
sentences.text: êwako tahtw-âskiy kita-tôtahkik ayîsiyiniwak kî-miyâwak
sentences.english: The people were given the annual performance of this rite.

sentences.original: êkwah ispîh kiskinôhamôwâw tânis ta-tôtahk;
sentences.text: êkwa ispî kiskinohamawâw tânisi ta-tôtahk
sentences.english: And at the same time he was taught how to perform it;

sentences.original: okîsikôwah kîh-kiskinôhamâk.
sentences.text: okîsikôwa kî-kiskinôhamâk
sentences.english: by the dwellers in the sky he was taught.

sentences.original: mâskôc nawac nawac tah-miywâsin kâkikê ta-pakitinamâht ayîsiyiniw; êwako nitêyihtênân.
sentences.text: mâskôc nawac nawac ta-miywâsin kâkikê ta-pakitinamâht ayîsiyiniw êwako nititêyihtênân
sentences.english: Surely it would be well, if it were always permitted to the Indian; so we think.

sentences.original: tahkih kêkway kitah-miy-ôhpikin.
sentences.text: tahki kêkway kita-miyo-ohpikin
sentences.english: Crops would always grow well.

sentences.original: namoya maci-kêkway nipâkwêsimôkamik.
sentences.text: namôya maci-kêkway nipâkwêsimowikamik
sentences.english: The Sun-Dance Lodge is not an evil thing.

sentences.original: wiyawâw, kahkiyaw kêkway maci-kêkway nêhiyawak maci-mantôwah atoskawêwak, itwêwak ayamihêw-iyiniwak.
sentences.text: wiyawâw itwêwak ayamihêw-iyiniwak
sentences.english: To be sure, “The Cree perform all kinds of evil things for the Evil Spirit,” say the missionaries.

sentences.original: namoya niynân nêhiyaw ôtah askihk ohcih kikih-pakitinâw;
sentences.text: namôya niyanân nêhiyaw ôta askihk ohci kiki-pakitinâw
sentences.english: On the contrary: the Cree was not put down here on earth with these things;

sentences.original: maci-manitôwah mîna manitôw okosisah namoya ohci kiskêyimêw nêhiyaw;
sentences.text: maci-manitôwa mîna manitôw okosisa namôya ohci kiskêyimêw nêhiyaw
sentences.english: the Cree has never known and does not know an Evil Spirit or a Son of God;

sentences.original: mînah maci-manitôw k-êsiyîhkâsot namoya nêhiyaw kiskêyimêw.
sentences.text: mîna maci-manitôw kâ-isiyîhkâsot namôya nêhiyaw kiskêyimêw
sentences.english: and the Cree does not know him who is called the Evil One.

sentences.original: âtah kita-kîh-tâpwêhtahk nêhiyaw, nawac manitôwah êh-kitimâkêyimikot, êkâ wîhkâc ohtinwah kâ-nipahikot.
sentences.text: âta kita-kî-tâpwêhtahk nêhiyaw nawac manitôwa ê-kitimâkêyimikot êkâ wîhkâc yôtinwa kâ-nipahikot
sentences.english: But rather, well may the Cree believe that the Spirit looks with kindlier pity on him, since he is never killed by winds.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik yôtin.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik yôtin
sentences.english: Never is a Cree killed by wind.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc nipahik nêhiyaw piyêsiwah.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc nipahik nêhiyaw piyêsiwa
sentences.english: Never is a Cree killed by the Thunderers.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik iskotêw.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik iskotêw
sentences.english: Never is a Cree killed by fire.

sentences.original: êkotah ohcih ntêyihtênân, nawac nêhiyaw êh-kitimâkinâkôwisit.
sentences.text: êkota ohci nititêyihtênân nawac nêhiyaw ê-kitimâkinâkôwisit
sentences.english: That is why we think that the Cree is favored by the Higher Powers.

sentences.original: mâskôc êh-kisiwahât manitôwah, nipâkwêsimôkamik êh-kipihtinahk, êwak ôhci mâh-mistahi k-ôh-pikonahkik môniyaw-ôtênawa, nitêyihtênân; mîn îskotêw tahto-kiskâw k-ôh-pîkonahk wâskahikanah;
sentences.text: mâskôc ê-kisiwâhât manitôwa nipâkwêsimowikamik ê-kipihtinahk êwako ohci mâh-mistahi kâ-ôh-pîkonahkik môniyâw-ôtênawa nititêyihtênân mîna iskotêw tahto-kîsikâw kâ-ôh-pîkonahk wâskahikana
sentences.english: Perhaps it is because he has angered the Spirit by putting a stop to the Sun-Dance Lodge, that in such numbers they break up the Canadian's towns; so we think; and that every day fire destroys the wooden houses;
sentences.footnote: LB on {k-ôh-pikonahkik}:  The actor “they” probably refers to the Thunderers.

sentences.original: tahto-kîsikâw misiwê nikiskêyihtênân ê-saskitêkih wâskahikanah, mayaw ôtênâhk êtohtêyâhkoh.
sentences.text: tahto-kîsikâw misiwê nikiskêyihtênân ê-saskitêki wâskahikana mayaw ôtênâhk êtohtêyâhko
sentences.english: every day we learn that everywhere houses have caught fire, every time we go to town.

sentences.original: mîna nipêhtênân tahto-nîpin êh-pîkwâstahkih pikw îtê ôtênawa.
sentences.text: mîna nipêhtênân tahto-nîpin ê-pîkwâstahki piko itê ôtênawa
sentences.english: And every summer we hear that in many places towns have been destroyed by windstorms.

sentences.original: namoya maci-kêkway kâ-kîh-miyikoyâhk manitôw, mawimoscikêwinah, nayêstaw kit-si-nitotamihk miyo-kêkway.
sentences.text: namôya maci-kêkway kâ-kî-miyikoyâhk manitôw mawimoscikêwina nayêstaw kita-isi-nitotamihk miyo-kêkway
sentences.english: It is not an evil thing which the Spirit has given to us, but ways of worship, only that good things may be prayed for.

sentences.original: êkosi nkîh-isih-pakitinikonân manitôw ôtah askîhk kâ-nêhiyawiyâhk.
sentences.text: êkosi nikî-isi-pakitinikonân manitôw ôta askîhk kâ-nêhiyâwiyâhk
sentences.english: Thus did the Spirit set us down here on earth, us who are Cree.

sentences.original: âtiht mâmaskâc mastaw êh-ihtakohkih nîmihitôwinah êkâ êh-kipihtinahk wâpiski-wiyâs, nanâtohk êy-isih-mêstinikêhk; mâka nipâkwêsimôwin nama kêkway mêstinikâniwa.
sentences.text: âtiht mâmaskâc mastaw ê-ihtakohki nîmihitôwina êkâ ê-kipihtinahk wâpiski-wiyâs nanâtohk ê-isi-mêstinikêhk mâka nipâkwêsimôwin nama kêkway mêstinikâniwa
sentences.english: Strange, that some dances which arose much later are not stopped by the White Man, dances in which various things are used up, while the Sun-Dance involves no waste.

sentences.original: nêhiyawak êkotah tahtw-âskiy kîh-miyâwak nîso-kîsikâw êkâh kita-mîcisocik, kita-ntotahkik kahkiyaw kêkway kita-miy-ôhpikiniyik, kita-ntotahkik ta-kimiwaniyik.
sentences.text: nêhiyawak êkota tahtw-âskiy kî-miyâwak nîso-kîsikâw êkâ kita-mîcisocik kita-nitotahkik kahkiyaw kêkway kita-miyo-ohpikiniyik kita-nitotahkik ta-kimiwaniyik
sentences.english: It was given to the Cree, every year, for two days to go without eating, and to pray that all things might grow well, and to pray for rain.

sentences.original: êkosi kâh-isi-pakitiniht ôt âskîhk kitimâkayîsiyiniw.
sentences.text: êkosi kâ-isi-pakitiniht ôta askîhk kitimâki-ayîsiyiniw
sentences.english: It was thus that the poor Indian was set down here on earth.

sentences.original: nika-miywêyihtên niya mîna wâhyaw kit-êtohtêmakahk pîkiskwêwin, êkâ êh-wâpiyan.
sentences.text: nika-miywêyihtên niya mîna wâhyaw kita-itohtêmakahk pîkiskwêwin êkâ ê-wâpiyân
sentences.english: I too shall be glad to have my speech go far abroad, I who am blind.

sentences.original: êkosi aspin êh-ohciyân namoya niwâpin.
sentences.text: êkosi aspin ê-ohciyân namôya niwâpin
sentences.english: For from the time I was born, I have been blind.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc askiy niwâpahtên.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc askiy niwâpahtên
sentences.english: Never have I seen the earth.

sentences.original: êkosi âskaw pikw îtê êh-itohtêyân nititohtân; nama wîhkâc niwanihon.
sentences.text: êkosi âskaw piko itê ê-itohtêyân nititohtân nama wîhkâc niwanihon
sentences.english: Yet when from time to time I mean to go anywhere,  I go there; I never get lost.

sentences.original: êkosi êyôkô pêyak âcimôwin êwako.
sentences.text: êkosi êwako pêyak âcimôwin êwako
sentences.english: So much for this, for this one story.
